workflow.label: AutoCore Workflow CAN Stack
workflow.description: The EB tresos workflow is a step-by-step instruction to guide you through the configuration of a project. The workflow represents a sequence of steps to accomplish the task of building an application.

group.label: Integrate a CAN communication stack into your basic software project
group.description:
Goal

To integrate a CAN communication stack into your basic software project.

The AutoCore Workflow CAN Stack helps you to add a CAN stack to your software component and to create a runnable software component that communicates via the CAN bus.

Preconditions

The AutoCore Workflow CAN Stack continues the AutoCore Workflow Rte. If you did not perform the steps as described in the AutoCore Workflow Rte, go through the AutoCore Workflow Rte before continuing with this CAN stack workflow.

Procedure

  1. Add new CAN-specific modules to your project.
  2. Import an ECU configuration.
  3. Run CAN assistants.
  4. Configure new modules.
  5. Update the configuration of other modules.
  6. Change, build and run your application.

Output

Note:

Names of dialogs, editors, importers, tables, tabs, etc. are displayed in italic font.

Buttons, text boxes, check boxes, drop-down list boxes and menu entries are displayed in bold font.

File, directory and path names, parameters and command line commands are displayed in Courier font.

Tip: A workflow step that is displayed with a green arrow icon is an action step. You may start the corresponding action by double-clicking the step or by clicking the Run button in the tool bar. A workflow step that is displayed with a red cross icon is an unavailable step. With your current selection in the Project Explorer view it is not possible to execute the corresponding action.

action.label: Generate BSW and SWC descriptions
action.description:
In EB tresos Studio you can generate AUTOSAR 3.2, 4.0, or 4.2 compliant BSW and SWC descriptions. Select the desired schema compliance to trigger the generation mode of the specific SWC description.

Under Project/Build Project/ select one of the following menu items to trigger the generation of SWC descriptions:
  • generate_asr32_swcd to generate AUTOSAR 3.2 compliant BSW SWC descriptions
  • generate_asr40_swcd to generate AUTOSAR 4.0 compliant BSW SWC descriptions
  • generate_swcd to generate AUTOSAR default BSW SWC descriptions

Double-click this action to generate AUTOSAR default BSW SWC descriptions.

action.label: Add modules
action.description:
Goal

To add all CAN stack modules to your project.

Procedure

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view to open the Module Configurations dialog.
  2. In the Available Modules tree, select all modules necessary for CAN communication:
    • Can (CAN Driver)
    • CanIf (CAN Interface)
    • CanSM (CAN State Manager)
    • Com (Communication)
    • ComM (Communication Manager)
    • EcuC (ECU Configuration)
    • PduR (PDU Router)
  3. Click the button Add module configurations for selected modules.
    Tip: Multiple selection of modules is possible: All CAN stack modules (except the CanNm module) are grouped together in the cluster Can Stack.
  4. Depending on your configuration file you may also add the following optional modules:
    • CanTp (CAN Transport Layer)
    • CanNm (CAN Network Management)
  5. Select PduR in the Module Configurations list and change the Recommended Configuration to PduRRecConfigurationCanEcu.
  6. Click OK.

group.label: Import CAN communication matrix description file
group.description:
The CAN communication matrix is represented in the DBC, Fibex or system description file format. Importing a .dbc file automatically configures a big part of the modules Can, CanIf, Com, EcuC and PduR (and other modules). The imported Fibex or system description file may additionally contain configuration data for the modules CanTp and CanNm.

  • To import a communication matrix from a system description, proceed to step Import from system description.
  • To import a communication matrix from a DBC file, proceed to step Import from DBC.
  • To import a communication matrix from a Fibex file, proceed to step Import from Fibex.

action.label: Import from system description
action.description:
1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Im- and Exporter dialog opens up.
  2. In the Create, manage and run im- and exporters dialog, select the system description importer you have added in the AutoCore Workflow Rte.
  3. Select the tab All Models and add the CAN system description at the second position.
  4. To apply your changes, click Apply.
  5. To import your CAN communication matrix into the ECU configuration, click the button Run Importer.
Application demos concrete examples:

Add CanSystem.arxml to the second position of Imp_System importer.

The importer should look like below:

  • output\generated\swcd\Base_Bswmd.arxml
  • supplement\SimpleDemo_SysDesc\system\CanSystem.arxml
  • supplement\SimpleDemo_SysDesc\system\SoftwareComponents.arxml
  • systemmod\ConnectionEditor.arxml
  • supplement\SimpleDemo_SysDesc\system\BswMMode.arxml
  • output\generated\swcd\*.arxml
Remark: it is mandatory to have the first two entries as defined here!

action.label: Import from DBC
action.description:
1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Im- and Exporter dialog opens up.
  2. Add a new DBC Importer by clicking on the Create a new im- or exporter button.
  3. On the New Importer/Exporter page, select DBC Importer in the Importer/Exporter drop-down list box and change the name of the importer. Proceed to the next page.
  4. On the All Models page, select the DBC file to be imported. Proceed to the next page.
  5. On the System Model Import page, clear the check box Override existing model. Otherwise your software components in the system model will be overwritten. Proceed to the next page.
  6. On the ECU Configuration Import page select the check box Enable ECU Configuration import.
  7. Click Finish.
  8. To import your CAN communication matrix into the ECU configuration, click the button Run Importer.

action.label: Import from Fibex
action.description:
1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Im- and Exporter dialog opens up.
  2. Add a new FIBEX Importer by clicking the Create a new im- or exporter button.
  3. On the New Importer/Exporter page, select FIBEX 1.x/2.0.x/3.x Importer in the Importer/Exporter drop-down list box and change the name of the importer. Proceed to the next page.
  4. On the All Models page, select the DBC file to be imported. Proceed to the next page.
    5. .
  5. On the System Model Import page clear the check box Override existing model. Otherwise your software components in the system model will be overwritten. Proceed to the next page.
  6. On the ECU Configuration Import page select the check box Enable ECU Configuration import.
  7. Click Finish.
  8. To import your CAN communication matrix into the ECU configuration, click the button Run Importer.

group.label: Import ECU configuration
group.description: After importing the system description the ECU configuration can be updated based on the current system model.

action.label: Configure ImportEcuConfig wizard
action.description:
1. To open the ImportEcuConfig wizard, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. Alternatively you can open the ImportEcuConfig wizard in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Unattended wizard configuration... The Unattended Wizards configuration window opens up, select Create ECU Configuration(ImportEcuConfig) entry from the left side list.
  2. Select the module configurations you want to import.
  3. Adjust Buffer Assignement in Can/CanIf according to your needs.

    Remark:Can buffer assignement can be edited later with a dedicated assistant!

  4. Click the Close button to close the wizard configuration dialog

action.label: Run ImportEcuConfig wizard
action.description:
1. To run the ImportEcuConfig wizard, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. Alternatively you can open the ImportEcuConfig wizard in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Unattended wizard configuration... The Unattended Wizards configuration window opens up, select Create ECU Configuration(ImportEcuConfig) entry from the left side list.
  2. Click the Run button to run the ImportEcuConfig wizard

group.label: Run assistant dialogs
group.description:
Assistant dialogs help you with the configuration of complex tasks and thus avoid time-consuming configuration work.

You can use the following assistance dialogs to configure the CAN communication stack:

  • CAN Buffer Assignment Editor
  • Handle ID Calculator

action.label: Edit CAN Buffer Assignment
action.description:
Goal

To assign PDUs to hardware buffers of the CAN controller.

The CAN Buffer Assignment Editor assigns transmit and receive PDUs (i.e. CAN messages) to hardware buffers that are located in the CAN controller. If two or more PDUs are assigned to the same buffer, the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor automatically calculates a filter mask and compares the CAN-IDs of the PDUs.

The upper half of the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor displays a list of all PDUs, in the lower half of the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor you can see a list of all available Hardware Object Handles (HOHs) (i.e. the CAN hardware buffers).

If you open the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor, a default buffer configuration is set, which assigns all received PDUs and all transmitted PDUs to a single buffer.

Procedure

To assign PDUs to buffers, follow these steps:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view to open the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor.
  2. Select all PDUs and click the button Clear selected PDUs.
  3. In the lower left corner of the CAN Buffer Assignment Editor, click the button Assign. All unassigned PDUs are assigned automatically to a buffer.
  4. Click Finish.

Note: The automatic assignment of PDUs is the most efficient way to assign PDUs to buffers and hence is the recommended way. For very complex configurations no valid assignment may be possible. In this case you have to assign the PDUs manually to the Hardware Object Handles.

action.label: Calculate Handle IDs
action.description:
Goal

To calculate the handle-IDs (i.e the PDU-IDs and controller-IDs) for the modules of the communication stack.

Procedure

  • To open the configuration dialog of the Handle ID Calculator, click the book icon in the tool bar of the Workflows view.
  • To calculate the handle-IDs, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Handle ID Calculator opens up and calculates automatically all handle-IDs.

Note: By default the Handle ID Calculator calculates all handle-IDs of the loaded modules.

group.label: Modify the remaining module configurations
group.description:
Goal

To configure the basic software modules in your project.

Procedure

You can change each basic software module configuration either by double-clicking the respective action step in the Workflows view or by double-clicking the module in the Project Explorer view.

Tip: To search for configuration parameter names project wide, use the keys Ctrl+T.

Configure the following modules manually:

  • Can: Set the protocol parameter, and change the behavior of the polling mode.
  • CanIf: Enable/disable the wakeup support.
  • ComM: Configure the ComM module.
  • CanSM: Configure the CanSM module.
  • PduR: Configure the PduR module.
  • Port: Connect I/O pins to the CAN transceiver.
  • BswM: Update the BswM module.
  • Rte: Update the data mapping.

action.label: Configure the Can module
action.description:
To configure the Can module:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Can editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  2. In the CanConfigSet tab, create a configuration unless the CAN communication matrix import has already created one.
  3. Make sure at least one configuration exists in the list CanController. For each controller choose between INTERRUPT and POLLING mode for the parameters CanRxProcessing, CanTxProcessing, CanWakeupProcessing and CanBusoffProcessing.
  4. Enable or disable wakeup support with the parameter CanWakeupSupport.
Note:

In case you choose INTERRUPT for at least one of the controller parameters, you will also have to configure the correct interrupt handlers in the OsIsr tab of the OS editor. Please refer to the documentation of your microcontroller to determine the correct settings.

action.label: Configure the CanIf module
action.description:
To configure the CanIf module:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The CanIf editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  2. If CanWakeupSupport is enabled in the Can module of your project, also enable CanIfCtrlWakeupSupport in the CanIf module and set the references CanIfCtrlWakeupSourceInRef and CanIfCtrlWakeupSourceOutRef to a valid wakeup source configured in the EcuM module.
  3. Set CanIfDispatchUserSetWakeupEventUL to ECUM .
  4. In the CanIfUpperLayerConfig tab, remove the entries for CAN_NM and CAN_TP.

action.label: Configure the ComM module
action.description:
To configure the ComM module:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The ComM editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  2. In the tab General, enable Enable Rte Usage. The ComM then provides a service component which can be connected to the application to request the communication mode.
  3. In the tab General, adapt the value of the parameter Minimum Full Communication Mode Duration Time to your needs. It specifies the minimum time until the ECU can be shut down.
  4. In the ComMConfigSet tab, create a configuration unless there is already one.
  5. In the tab Users, add a new configuration if there is not already an existing entry.
  6. In the tab Network Channel, add a new configuration and enter the configuration.
  7. Set the Bus Type to COMM_BUS_TYPE_CAN.

  8. If you do not have a CanNm module in your project, set the Network Management Variant to NONE.

    If your system description file contains a configuration for Can Network Management, you must have added the module CanNm as mentioned in step Add modules. In this case, select FULL. Ensure you configure the module CanNm, too. Note that configuring the module CanNm is not part of this workflow.

  9. Open the tab User Per Channel, add an entry and set the reference.
  10. Verify ComMDcmUsage parameter is set to false, as normally Dcm module is not part of an application demo projects.

action.label: Configure the CanSM module
action.description:
To configure the CanSM module:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The CanSM editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  2. In the tab List of Configurations, add a new configuration.
  3. In the tab List of CAN Networks, add a CAN network and set the reference to ComM Channel.
  4. Add a reference to the List of CAN Controllers and set the reference CAN Controller.

action.label: Configure the PduR module
action.description:
To configure the PduR module:

  1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The PduR editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  2. In the tab PduRBswModules, disable the parameter PdurBswModuleIsEnable for all modules except the entries for the modules CanIf and Com.

action.label: Configure the Port module
action.description:
Goal

To configure the I/O pins that connect the CAN core with the CAN transceiver by configuring the module Port.

The configuration of different MCAL driver implementations may differ from each other. In addition, the configuration depends on the connected CAN transceiver.

Note: This configuration step is hardware-dependent.

Procedure

If required by your hardware, configure the following pins:

Pins out:

  • Transmit Data (Tx)
  • Enable
  • Standby

Pins in:

  • Receive Data (Rx)
  • Error line

For a proper mode and pin number selection, refer to the manual of your microcontroller.

action.label: Configure the BswM module
action.description:
Goal

To configure the BswM module, which initializes and activates several other modules.

In case a window pops up which asks you to select between a BswM Editor and a Generic Editor, you may simply close this window by clicking on the Cancel button.

To make this configuration step easier, you can import the configuration file BswM_simple_demo_can_rte_additions.epc from the folder supplement/SimpleDemo_EPCs\epc, which is located in the directory demos/AutoCore of your EB tresos Studio installation. Therefore, you have to create a new Autosar Importer.

Procedure

To import the configuration file BswM_simple_demo_can_rte_additions.epc:

  1. First, copy the directory supplement\SimpleDemo_EPCs (located in demos\...\supplement in your EB tresos Studio installation) to the project directory of your EB tresos Studio project. This step is recommended because EB tresos Studio will then use paths relative to the project directory instead of storing absolute file paths.
  2. Right-click your project in the Project Explorer view. A context menu opens up.
  3. Select the menu item Im- and Exporters.... The Create, manage and run im- and exporters dialog opens up.
  4. Add a new Autosar Importer by clicking the Add button. The New Importer/Exporter wizard opens up.

    5. On the New Importer/Exporter page of the New Importer/Exporter wizard:

    • In the Name text box, type the name of your importer.
    • In the Importer/Exporter drop-down list box, choose Autosar Im-/Exporter.
    • In the Mode drop-down list box, select Import only.
    • Click Next to proceed to the Autosar Options page.

    On the Autosar Options page:

    • Click the Browse... button and browse to the file workspace/<PROJECT_NAME>/supplement/SimpleDemo_EPCs/epc/BswM_simple_demo_can_rte_additions.epc.
    • In the Content type drop-down list box, select the version asc:4.0.3.
    • In the Import Strategy drop-down list box, select Merge.
    • Click Finish. The New Importer/Exporter wizard closes.
  5. To start the import, click the Run Importer button in the lower left corner of the Create, manage and run im-and exporters dialog. The BswM configuration is being updated.

Application demo related information:

In case you want to use the PbcfgM module in your application, please set the BswM Config Variant to VariantPostBuild.

If the seetings of the configuration parameters BswMMaxNumActionLists and BswMMaxNumRules are outdated after the import, click on the Calculate Value button next to the configuration parameters.

The BswM configuration will be extended to get access to all communication relevant states. With this information the BswM is able to start/stop the communication. Mode request ports are used to access the communication relevant states. The mode request ports for ComM, CanSM and to SWC_CyclicCounter will be added to the BswM configuration. Additionally, new rules which enable/disable the communication are added. There will be also some rules added to handle the shutdown and the restart of the ECU.

action.label: Calculate Dem, NvM and EcuM service needs

command.description: Open the Service Needs Calculator configuration

action.description:
The Service Needs Calculator automatically resolves most dependencies between the different modules. For example, it adds required Dem events to the Dem configuration, required init functions to the EcuM module and required NvM blocks to the NvM module.

It is recommended that you run the Service Needs Calculator before the step Update Service Component and BSWM Descriptions as this mentioned step requires a consistent ECU configuration.

  • To open the configuration dialog of the Service Needs Calculator, click the book icon in the tool bar of the Workflows view. Alternatively you can find the configuration dialog in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Unattended wizard configuration
  • To run the Service Needs Calculator, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. Alternatively you can run the Service Needs Calculator in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Calculate Service Needs

action.label: Update BSW and SWC descriptions in the system model
action.description:
The wizard generates and import the BSW and SWC descriptions for all the enabled BSW modules

This step is a prerequisite for the main-function-to-task mapping and of the configuration of the BSW exclusive area in the Rte.

After this step, the service components are available and can be connected to the application software components.

  • To run the MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions, double-click this action step in the Workflows view.
  • Alternatively you can run the MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Execute multiple tasks(MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions)

action.label: Run Compositions and Connections Editor
action.description:
1. To run the Compositions and Connections Editor, double-click this action step in the Workflows view or select Edit Compositions and Connections from the category System in the Sidebar view. If the System and EcuInstance have not yet been selected for the given project, then the Select system and ecuInstance dialog opens up.
    • In the System drop-down list box, select a system from the system description. In the EcuInstance drop-down list box, select an ECU from the system description.
    • Click OK to proceed to the Compositions and Connections Editor.
  2. Add Component Prototypes:
    1. Right-click on TopLevelComposition in the Entity list and select Add Prototypes....
    2. Select the ComM checkbox.
    3. Click OK to add a component prototype for each selected component type
  3. Add connections:
    1. To make the assignment, expand a prototype, right-click on the prototype's port and select Add Connector.... Then expand a component prototype and select a port.If the OK button is not enabled, then the selected port is not compatible. With the buttons on top of the dialog you can restrict the entities of the Tree to show or hide incompatible ports and already connected ports. With the type filter text you can restrict the shown ports by name. Click OK to add the connection.
      • For a concrete example, see an application demo hint below the text
Application demos concrete examples:

  • In the assignment of Compositions and Connections Editor, assign the following prototype and port:

    ComM_Prototype/UR_ComMUser_0 -> SWC_CyclicCounter/UR_ComMUser_0

action.label: Run EcuExtractCreator wizard
action.description: To run the EcuExtractCreator wizard, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. Alternatively you can run the EcuExtractCreator wizard in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Creates an ecu extract (EcuExtractCreator)

action.label: Configure the Rte module
action.description:
1. Double-click this action step in the Workflows view. The Select Editor dialog opens up.
  2. Select Rte Editor. The Rte Editor opens up in the editor area of EB tresos Studio.
  3. Open the tab Data Mapping.
    • Map the data element prototypes to Com signals or system signals.
  4. Open the Event Mapping tab.
    • Auto-map all Bsw main functions that are triggered by Bsw timing events.
    • To auto-map all Bsw main functions click the button Auto-map all Bsw main functions that are triggered by Bsw timing events
    • Map all remaining events that have the Required flag set to true to a task.
    • To map an event to a task, select a task in the Task drop-down list box and click the button Map the runnable entity selected above to the task selected below.
    • Map timing events and non-timing events to separate tasks.

Note: Since the import of the CAN communication matrix may have overwritten previous changes to your AUTOSAR system, check again the Rte configuration steps described in the AutoCore Workflow Rte.
Application demos concrete examples:

  • In the assignment of Data Mapping, assign the following signals:

    /ComConfig/SGCounterIn_256R -> TopLevelComposition/SWC_ModifyEcho/R_NewCounterIn

    /ComConfig/SGCounterOut_272T -> TopLevelComposition/SWC_CyclicCounter/P_CounterOut

action.label: Calculate Os service needs

command.description: Open the Service Needs Calculator configuration

action.description:
It is recommended that you run the Service Needs Calculator again to add the Os objects required by the Rte module to the Os configuration. Since this requires a consistent Rte configuration, this step is recommended after you have completed the step Configure Rte module.

  • To open the configuration dialog of the Service Needs Calculator, click the book icon in the tool bar of the Workflows view. Alternatively you can find the configuration dialog in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Unattended wizard configuration
  • To run the Service Needs Calculator, double-click this action step in the Workflows view. Alternatively you can run the Service Needs Calculator in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Calculate Service Needs

action.label: Update system model
action.description:
The wizard generates and import the BSW and SWC descriptions for all the enabled BSW modules

The last steps have changed the ECU configuration, on which the BSWMD depends. Thus, it is recommended to update the basic software module description again.

  • To run the MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions, double-click this action step in the Workflows view.
  • Alternatively you can run the MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions in the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Execute multiple tasks(MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions)

group.label: Update Execute multiple tasks wizards
group.description:
Goal

To Update Execute multiple tasks to ease the execution of different steps.

The Execute multiple tasks wizards can be used to serialize the execution of several actions.

The following actions are available:

  • Run importer
  • Run exporter
  • Run unattended wizard
  • Run code generation
  • Run an external command

Application demos concrete examples:

To ease the creation and update of the Application demo two Execute multiple tasks wizard are created:

  • MultiTask_UpdateBswDescriptions: to update the system model based on the current BSW configuration
  • MultiTask_RunFullImport: to import the complete system description
At this step we want to update the MultiTask_RunFullImport wizard to include the ImportEcuConfig wizard

action.label: Import System description
action.description:
To update an Execute multiple tasks wizard:

  1. Go to the menu Project -> Unattended Wizards -> Unattended wizard configuration... The Unattended Wizards configuration window opens up
  2. Select the Execute multiple tasks(MultiTask_RunFullImport) element from the list in the left side window.
  3. On the right side window press the plus button to create a new task for the ImportEcuConfig
    • In the Action column select Run unattended wizard
    • In the Parameter column select ImportEcuConfig
  4. Using the arows position the ImportEcuConfig entry above the AutoHandleId entry.
  5. Click Close to close the Unattended wizards configuration window

group.label: Build your application
group.description:
Goal

To generate code, build your application and run your application.

Preconditions

If you have performed all steps that are described in the AutoCore Workflow Rte, there are some C source files in your project already.

Procedure

  1. Generate code
  2. Build your application
  3. Run your application

Output

The application code will be located in the Project Explorer view in the directory source\application. This application code belongs to your project.

action.label: Generate code
action.description: Start the generation of your project configuration code by double-clicking this action step in the Workflows view or by clicking the hammer icon in the tool bar of EB tresos Studio.

action.label: Build your application
action.description:
To make your application running you have to create a binary for your target platform.

To create a binary for your target platform:

  1. Execute launch.bat
  2. To compile and link your software components, type make.

action.label: Run your application
action.description:
Your finished application binary is located in the directory output\bin.

You can use a debugger (e.g. Lauterbach) to download your application to your target ECU.

Note: To test the CAN communication on the bus, you must connect at least a second CAN node. EB tresos Busmirror can emulate a complete CAN (and FlexRay) network to test your application. EB tresos Inspector can monitor and analyze your CAN (and FlexRay/LIN) bus traffic.

action.label: Finish
action.description:
You have built your CAN stack application successfully.

You may continue with the Memory Stack Workflow , or Post-Build Setup Workflow which are based on the CAN stack Workflow and which contains instructions for upgrading your CAN stack Workflow with Memory Stack or Post-Build support.
